name: AI Travel App PRD
description: Realistic PRD evolution with cumulative edits by product, engineering, legal, GTM, and exec.

payload.title: Product Requirements Document for Atlas Travel Copilot

versions.content:
ATLAS TRAVEL COPILOT
Product Requirements Document
Owner: Maya Ortiz, Head of Product
Status: Working draft

Product Goal
Atlas converts freeform trip intent into complete day plans that users can act on immediately. Inputs include destination, dates, budget, constraints, and preference signals.

Launch Plan in Current Draft
Public beta date is March 20.
Initial market coverage includes United States, Japan, Italy, and Thailand.
Launch narrative assumes broad availability and complete plan-to-action flow.

Scope in Current Draft
One-prompt itinerary generation.
Hotel and activity recommendations.
Flight and hotel booking links.
Editable day-by-day planner.
Shareable itinerary links.

Performance and Reliability Expectations
p95 generation target under 10 seconds.
Confidence cues should be visible but lightweight.
Supplier freshness checks should run before rendering recommendations.

Success Metrics
Itinerary completion rate above 85 percent.
Booking-link click-through above 20 percent.
Day-14 retention above 24 percent.

Risks
Supplier reliability variability.
Stale pricing and availability mismatch.
User trust degradation if output quality drops during peak demand.

Open Questions
How much detail should first response include versus speed.
Whether multi-city itinerary is required in beta scope.
Whether confidence labels should be mandatory in all plan sections.

ATLAS TRAVEL COPILOT
Product Requirements Document
Owner: Maya Ortiz
Updated by: Ravi Menon, Engineering Lead
Status: Working draft

Product Goal
Atlas converts freeform trip intent into complete day plans with alternatives users can review and edit.

Launch Plan in Current Draft
Public beta date is now treated as target, not fixed commitment.
Rollout moves to gated beta in Q2 based on reliability thresholds.
Initial rollout markets are narrowed to United States and Japan.

Scope in Current Draft
One-prompt itinerary generation.
Hotel and activity recommendations.
Editable day-by-day planner.
Shareable itinerary links.
Flight and hotel booking links removed from phase-one scope and deferred.

Performance and Reliability Expectations
p95 target updated to under 15 seconds for beta readiness.
Reliability target added: blank-itinerary failure below 2 percent for two consecutive weeks.
Incident runbook and on-call ownership required before invite expansion.

Engineering Findings Informing Edits
Production-like tests showed p95 between 19 and 28 seconds.
Supplier timeout clusters created partial itinerary render in approximately 11 to 16 percent of requests.
Retry behavior currently amplifies queue congestion during upstream instability.

Success Metrics
Completion and retention targets retained.
Booking-link click-through moved to phase-two metric set.

Risks
Primary near-term risk is reliability-led trust failure at launch.
Supplier dependency risk remains material.

Open Questions
Whether confidence labeling can offset deferred booking actions in phase one.
Whether latency goals are realistic without architectural fallback improvements.

ATLAS TRAVEL COPILOT
Product Requirements Document
Owners: Product and Engineering
Updated by: Alina Zhou, Legal Counsel
Status: Working draft

Product Goal
Atlas provides informational travel planning suggestions and editable day plans.

Launch Plan in Current Draft
Q2 gated beta remains plan.
No fixed public date may be communicated before legal and privacy sign-off.

Scope in Current Draft
One-prompt itinerary generation.
Hotel and activity recommendations.
Editable day-by-day planner.
Shareable itinerary links.
Confidence cues and limitation disclosures included.
Terms acknowledgment required before first itinerary generation.
Profile deletion workflow required.
Direct booking links remain deferred.

Mandatory Legal and Privacy Requirements
User-facing language must state recommendations are informational and not guaranteed availability, pricing, or safety advice.
Terms acceptance must occur before first itinerary request.
Passport and government-ID data collection is prohibited in MVP.
Recommendation generation and acknowledgment events must be auditable.

Performance and Reliability Expectations
Reliability gates from engineering revision remain in force.
p95 beta target remains under 15 seconds.
Blank-itinerary failure threshold remains below 2 percent for two consecutive weeks.

Success Metrics
Completion and retention targets retained.
Policy-violation tracking added as launch health metric.

Risks
Legal non-compliance risk now equals reliability risk in launch decisioning.
Paid placement concepts are blocked pending disclosure framework.

Open Questions
Whether geo-specific disclaimer variants are required.
Whether under-18 access should be restricted in initial release.

ATLAS TRAVEL COPILOT
Product Requirements Document
Owners: Product, Engineering, Legal
Updated by: Niko Brandt, GTM Lead
Status: Working draft

Product Goal
Atlas provides travel planning assistance and aims to become a repeat discovery and planning surface over time.

Launch Plan in Current Draft
Q2 gated beta remains unchanged.
No fixed public launch date remains unchanged.

Scope in Current Draft
Phase-one scope remains planning-first:
One-prompt itinerary generation.
Hotel and activity recommendations.
Editable day-by-day planner.
Shareable itinerary links.
Terms acknowledgment and profile deletion.
Confidence and limitation disclosures.

GTM Proposal Added to Strategy Section
Destination inspiration feed proposed for growth.
Social itinerary card format proposed for distribution.
Referral loop proposed for post-plan conversion.

Cross-Functional Review Notes Captured in Draft
Engineering notes that adding new surfaces before reliability gates increases launch risk.
Legal notes referral concept may be viable, but sponsored placement requires disclosure design and review.
Product notes that phase-one trust and reliability commitments should not be diluted.

Current Resolution in Draft
Discovery and referral ideas remain in strategy section only.
They are listed as phase-two candidates, not phase-one commitments.

Risks
Risk of narrative drift toward breadth before trust baseline is established.
Risk of execution overload if growth surfaces are pulled into phase one.

Open Questions
Can launch-quarter demand goals be reached through messaging and partnerships without adding product surfaces in phase one.

ATLAS TRAVEL COPILOT
Product Requirements Document
Owners: Executive Staff with Product, Engineering, Legal, GTM
Status: Approved direction

Product Goal
Atlas launches as a trust-first planning product and expands into broader discovery only after quality gates are met.

Launch Plan
Phased beta in Q2 is approved.
No fixed public launch date until all gates are complete.

Final Phase-One Scope
One-prompt itinerary generation.
Hotel and activity recommendations.
Editable day-by-day planner.
Shareable itinerary links.
Terms acknowledgment and profile deletion workflow.
Confidence cues and limitation disclosures.

Deferred to Phase Two
Direct booking links.
Destination inspiration feed.
Referral loop.
Paid placements.

Launch Gates
Legal and privacy sign-off complete.
Policy violation rate below 1 percent.
Reliability thresholds sustained for two consecutive weeks.
Incident ownership and escalation process tested.

Ownership Model
Product and Legal co-own launch readiness checklist.
Engineering owns reliability operations and incident process.
GTM owns external messaging within approved constraints.

Risk Posture
Primary launch risk remains trust failure from reliability or compliance miss.
Expansion risk is managed by explicit phase sequencing.

Decision Note
This version keeps prior cross-functional constraints and resolves conflict through ordered rollout rather than scope inflation.
